title: Did the Mongols try to invade Japan? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes, Mongols tried to invade Japan twice. The first attempt by Kublai Khan in 1274 after conquest of Korea. Mongols invaded some islands and killed basically everyone they faced in smaller skirmishes. However they were defeated in the battle of Torikai after which retreaded to their ships. An untimly typhoon hit the ships ending the first invasion. This is where the name “kamikaze” comes from, meaning “divine wind”. Kublai Khan tried for a second invasion in 1281 with a much larger force but Japanese were better prepared. Mongols had a huge fleet that was very hard to provision so they were slowed down in the entire campaign. Japanese fortified the islands with high walls so Mongols never really had the chance to disembark the entire army. Japanese won most of the skirmishes and once Mongols retreaded back to their ships another kamikaze hit the shores for two days straight destroying majority of the Mongol forces. Even though Mongols had the strong Korean ships, most of the fleet were made of Chinese river boats that couldn’t handle the storms. There’s historical talk about a 3rd invasion which has never been initiated.

They did not. They attempted it twice (first in 1274 then in 1281), but it didn’t work out either time. The weather turned out to be very much against the Mongols. The first invasion involved a relatively modest force of a little over 20,000 Mongols and allied troops. They met with some initial success, though resistance was stiffening, when a storm caught most of Mongols out at sea and destroyed the bulk of the fleet and the embarked troops with them. The Japanese were able to mop up the few remaining Mongols with little trouble. The second invasion was much larger, nearly 150,000 total troops, though more Chinese and other vassals than Mongols. Once again, the invading army met with mixed success. The Mongol-led armies outnumbered the Japanese, but the Japanese had constructed some very good coastal defenses, keeping the Mongol forces at bay. And, once again, a tremendous storm struck, destroying much of the Mongol armada.

No. They did manage to seize a few islands off the Japanese coast and overwhelm the defenders there but their main invasion fleet both times encountered large storms and were scattered and or destroyed. The Japanese named these storms “Kamikaze” (divine wind) (神風) and they were the inspiration for the Japanese suicide attack aircraft from late 1944 and on. Although the term is in general use, pilots of damaged aircraft who turned their mortally damaged plane into a bomb where generally not given that name until after the kamikaze corp was born.

Yes, twice - in 1274 and 1281. In fact Kublai Khan was considering a 3rd invasion, but other closer events took up his attention. If you go to Fukuoka in Japan you can still see some remnants of the 20km of beachfront walls put up to keep the Mongols out in the 2nd invasion. There are a couple of small museums there as well, such as next to Higashi Park - but not visited much, so it's mostly open only on weekends.

The Devine Wind i.e "Kamikaze" was the storm that wrecked the Mongol's fleet. "When they landed on Hakata Bay, however, they met fierce resistance by the armies of samurai clans and were forced to withdraw to the Yuan dynasty. In the midst of the withdrawal, they were hit by a typhoon. Most of their ships sank and many soldiers were drowned." Kamikaze (typhoon)  Kamikaze – The Divine Winds that Saved Japan

The mongol never set the invasion of Japan and neither of certain East Asian nations as their military goal.

Mongolia never attacked Japan. Don’t believe Mongolia even had a standing military, many airplanes or any navy at all.
